Title.evidence: The iPREDICT Study: A Randomised Controlled Trial on Interactive Consultation Tool for Anaesthesia Risk Education

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults scheduled for elective surgery under general or combined anaesthesia.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to receive either ICT-based online anaesthesia risk education (intervention) or a control video without anaesthetic risk content.

Objective.evidence: The iPREDICT study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an interactive consultation tool (ICT) in enhancing patient awareness of anaesthesia-related risks during preoperative anaesthetic assessment (PAA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the perioperative risk knowledge score, assessed immediately after PAA and two days later.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a cryptographically secure pseudo-random number generator, with allocation concealed within the software.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible for patients or clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 373 participants were randomised (186 to ICT, 187 to control)

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 275 participants (139 ICT, 136 control) using a per-protocol approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The ICT group demonstrated a higher median risk knowledge score post-PAA (13.0 vs. 11.0, p < 0.05) and further improvement at follow-up (14.0 vs. 13.0, p < 0.05).

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by the University Hospital Bonn.
